title: Prime Directive: Amazon Daily Deals for Geeks
text:
The Internet is where we do most of our shopping, and a solid 90% of it is done at Amazon. Jeff Bezos has turned his humble bookstore into a sort of Automat of the digital age, selling everything from soup to nuts at low prices with speedy shipping. Nobody knows Amazon deals quite like we do. Except for you, that is. Welcome to Prime Directive, where we find the coolest things on Amazon.com and feed them to you, one at a time.
2/22/2017 Yoogo Self-Defense Keychain 
It’s a dangerous world out there if you listen to the TV news, with anti-American forces massing on every corner to burn innocent garbage cans and hassle people who just want to be racist in peace. Sure, you could apply for a concealed carry permit and pack a gun wherever you go, but those things are just so bulky. Why not opt for a way to increase your hand-to-hand lethality that is affordable and portable?
Enter the Yoogo Self-Defense Keychain, a shaped device that fits inside your hand and adds oomph to your punching and slashing motions without compromising your grappling ability. This thing comes with free online training materials to teach you how to use it and it’s engraved with a unique serial number in case you lose it. Pump up the power of your punch and take back those mean streets, Double Dragon style.
$19.99 from Amazon Prime, Buy it here 
Get $8.62 off with the coupon code BIGTHANKS today only!
2/21/2017 Scott Pilgrim’s Precious Little Boxset 
Happy birthday Bryan Lee O’Malley, the indie cartoonist who made good by getting his breakthrough work adapted into a Hollywood movie. Although the cinematic adaptation of Scott Pilgrim’s Precious Little Life didn’t set the world on fire, it’s still a fun and fast-paced action-comedy-romance with some great performances and a kick-ass soundtrack.
That said, if you haven’t read the original comic series you’re missing out. The six-volume epic gives the story’s Toronto location and supporting cast room to breathe, and the many clever video game and pop culture references are like catnip for true geeks. You can get them in a slick box set with an exclusive poster by clicking on that lovely link below.
$44.35 from Amazon Prime, Buy it here 
2/20/2017 Space Hulk 
Games Workshop is most famous for the <Warhammer strategy game, but for our money the best title in their catalogue is Space Hulk . Abandoning the wide-open battlefields of their other games, this one pits marines against aliens in claustrophobic corridors. One player controls a team of Space Marines tasked with investigating derelict vessels. Lurking in wait are Tyranids who just can’t wait to eat them.
Yes, this sounds a lot like a famous movie franchise, but so what? It’s also a fantastically fun and replayable two-player boardgame that looks great and is expertly balanced. This is the game’s fourth and most recent edition, and it’s on Amazon for a truly nice price.
$119.97 from Amazon Prime, Buy it here 
2/17/2017 Phantasm Special Edition Box Set 
62 years ago today one of the horror world’s most unique and idiosyncratic directors was born. Don Coscarelli didn’t come from a connected Hollywood family, but his near-psychotic love of the movies led to him becoming the youngest director in history to sell a flick to a major studio with Jim the World’s Greatest , made when he was just nineteen. But Coscarelli’s most notable achievement is the Phantasm series, a horror epic like nothing else.
The flicks follow two friends, Mike and Reggie, as they deal with a supernatural entity known as the Tall Man. As played by the late Angus Scrimm, the Tall Man is one of horror’s classic villains, a menacing and inscrutable figure accompanied by revived corpses and floating steel spheres equipped with all manner of weaponry. If you’re not on board, pick up this super-swank box set of the five films on Blu-Ray with tons of commentary and special features.
$79.99 from Amazon Prime, Buy it here 
2/16/2017 Runaways: The Complete Collection 
Marvel’s nickname as the “Hosue of Ideas” was believable back in the 60s and 70s, but as of late the company hasn’t had as much success creating franchises with staying power. One notable exception is Brian K. Vaughan and Adrian Alphona’s Runaways , which first debuted on this day in 2003. With a setting under-explored in the Marvel universe (Los Angeles) and few ties to current continuity, it was a great jumping-on point for new readers and quickly developed a fan following.
The series followed six kids who discover that their parents are members of a super-criminal syndicate called the Pride. Using their wits, newly-discovered powers and stolen weaponry, they rebel against the older generation and the unsavory elements who would take their place. Here’s a collection of the first eighteen issues so you can get ready for the upcoming Hulu adaptation.
$18.08 from Amazon Prime, Buy it here 
2/15/2017 Orphan Black: Season One 
On this date in 2001, a major scientific milestone was passed: the first draft of the human genome was published in the pages of Nature . This was an incredible leap forward for the project, which had been sequencing data feverishly for decades. From here, scientists were able to dig deep into the blueprint of humanity, gaining advanced understanding of what causes our bodies to grow the way they do.
Many, many TV shows have used genetic engineering as a plot device, but none delve quite so much into the repercussions as Orphan Black . The BBC series is notable not only for Tatiana Maslany’s virtuoso performance as a host of clones, but also for the way it examines the ethics of creating life from this blueprint. If by some unpleasant miracle you’ve missed it, here’s a super good deal on the show’s first season.
$18.08 from Amazon Prime, Buy it here 
2/14/2017 Catherine: Love Is Over 
Very few video games deal with the complex and thorny subject of love and relationships. It’s just too hard to make it seem realistic and believable. One cult hit that dared try it was quirky puzzle game Catherine , which covered everything in a surreal sauce to make things more exciting. When 32 year old Vincent wakes up next to a beautiful blonde after a night of drinking, he becomes the fulcrum of a love triangle that threatens to ruin his entire life.
This is the insanely deluxe limited edition of the game, which comes with as much swag as humanly possible. The heart-covered boxers Vincent wears in his dreams? You get a pair. A pillow with the comely Catherine on it? Sure. A T-shirt? A pizza box? Prints? Yes, yes, yes. And you get the game, too.
$138.60 from Amazon Prime, Buy it here 
2/13/2017 Rocketbook Wave Smart Notebook 
We’re obviously crazy about innovation here at Geek. We love it when people think outside the box. But we also love old-school stuff like writing down notes with pen and paper. Today’s Amazon pick blends those two things together in a way that’s both seamless and ridiculous. Meet the Rocketbook Wave Smart Notebook, which lets you jot down notes, doodles, and the like, then use their app to instantly digitize them. With built-in sharing functionality, you can automatically upload to Dropbox, Google Drive, iCloud and more. But here’s the big thing: the pages are erasable, even if you write with pen.
How do you erase it? In the most badass and bizarre way possible: you put the notebook in the microwave and nuke it. No matter how impractical and weird this is, we have to love the ingenuity. You can perform this task as many as 5 times with a single notebook, giving you tons of reusability. Sure, it’s a gimmick, but it’s a freaking awesome one.
$26.99 from Amazon Prime, Buy it here 
2/10/2017 Madman 20th Anniversary Monster 
We just spent a week talking about the reams of insanely great comics published by Image over their 25 year history and didn’t even mention Michael Allred’s Madman . That should be a testament to how deep the publisher’s bench is that one of the greatest alt-superhero books of the last few decades can get lost in the shuffle. Why don’t we rectify that right now with this incredible collection Image put out to honor his 20th anniversary of the hero?
To really illustrate how amazing Image is, they pulled out all the stops for this giant 11×17, 264 page full-color hardcover. Not only does it contain plenty of adventures my Madman’s creator Mike Allred, but also a veritable Who’s Who of the comics world – Jack Kirby! Frank Miller! Alex Toth! Peter Bagge! Paul Pope! Los Bros Hernandez! This is, without a doubt, the best Benjamin you can spend on comics today.
$100.00 from Amazon Prime, Buy it here 
2/9/2017 Electric Dual Arc Lighter 
Part of being a true geek is realizing that there’s always a better way to do things. Science is our best friend, and there’s nothing that can’t be improved with a little technological upgrade. Case in point: why would you ever light a fire with a traditional butane lighter when you can spark up – literally – with a lighter that uses two arcs of electricity to create the necessary heat?
Here’s a brief list of why this thing is sweeter than a traditional lighter: you can recharge it with any USB port. It doesn’t give a crap about wind, so you don’t have to flick it in between your cupped hands or whatever. And you won’t accidentally burn your fingers unless you’re a total idiot. If you’re packing your bugout bag, it’ll pay to have one of these.
$17.99 from Amazon Prime, Buy it here 
2/8/2017 Robot Chicken Seasons 1-5 
Happy birthday to Seth Green, who parlayed an acting career into creating and producing one of the most purely geeky shows ever to air on television: Robot Chicken . The long-running Adult Swim series has been on the air for a flabbergasting 12 years at this point, using low-budget stop-motion animation to skewer everything from Star Wars to politics. The ramshackle nature of the production only makes it funnier.
Why not give Green a few extra pennies on his royalty check by picking up this box set of the show’s first five seasons, containing hundreds of quick-hit spoofs and mash-ups that will tickle your funnybone. We could fill a whole page just with the insane bevy of guest voices, which include everybody from Don Knotts to Mila Kunis.
$123.11 from Amazon Prime, Buy it here 
2/7/2017 Joking Hazard 
When you think of long-running webcomics that have managed to keep the quality up, not very many names come to mind. One that does is Cyanide & Happiness , the resolutely negative strip by Rob DenBleyker, Kris Wilson and Dave McElfatrick that has been going since 2004. The strip stars an interchangeable parade of lumpy, Playmobil-looking people dealing with remarkably dark topics.
In 2016, the creators launched a Kickstarter for a card game based on the strip, and lo! here it is! Joking Hazard harnesses all the snark and negativity of the comic strip and lets you win points for it. Each player is dealt a hand of cards and has to complete a three-panel strip to the satisfaction of a Judge, who changes each round. It’s sort of Cards Against Humanity with comics – what could be better than that?
$23.62 from Amazon Prime, Buy it here 
2/6/2017 The Definitive Document Of The Dead 
Saturday was the 70th birthday of one of the most important figures in horror cinema, the great George Romero. The Bronx-born director got his start making clips for Mr. Rogers’ Neighborhood , but his heart was always in the darkness. In 1968, he released Night Of The Living Dead , the grim, claustrophobic black & white zombie movie that inspired a whole genre.
Document of the Dead is a 1979 documentary that was filmed while Romero was working on the classic Dawn of the Dead . It’s the absolute best peek into Romero’s life and methodology ever released, and this extended 102 minute cut with new audio commentary is a must for any zombie fan. The myriad filmic influences that inspire Romero’s vision are laid bare, and the director is remarkably honest about the collaborative, communal nature of his process. Definitely well worth owning.
$23.39 from Amazon Prime, Buy it here 
2/3/2017 Daredevil: Born Again 
It’s not unfair to say that for the first chunk of his career Daredevil (who debuted to day in 1964) was an unabashed B-lister. In a New York clogged with super-heroes, he didn’t really stand out as well as Spider-Man. That all changed when a young upstart named Frank Miller was assigned to the title in 1979. Miller transformed the underperforming book into one of Marvel’s top sellers, ably assisted by David Mazzuchelli. He embraced the visual medium of comics to portray DD’s enhanced senses in new and innovative ways.
He left the book for a spell, but was lured back in 1986 to pen Born Again , which basically laid the groundwork for every modern interpretation of the character. In it, Matt Murdock’s ex-girlfriend Karen Page sells his secret identity out to the Kingpin, who proceeds to completely destroy Daredevil’s life, both public and private. It’s a gripping, beautifully-told story that grapples with a bunch of remarkably mature issues for the era. Definitely a must-read.
$15.67 from Amazon Prime, Buy it here 
2/2/2017 Onyx Smart Walkie Talkies 
If you grew up in the pre cell phone generation, you probably have fond memories of talking to your friends late at night through a pair of staticky Radio Shack walkie-talkies. Before we were constantly connected via the Internet, short-range radio was the best way to transmit secrets, share gossip and plan pranks. One of the coolest new tech products we’ve seen recently re-invents the walkie into something seriously futuristic and cool.
The Onyx Smart Walkie Talkies from Orion Labs are a pair of button-sized, touch-activated devices that pair with your smartphone and a free app. Hook them up, invite friends and you can activate it with a single touch and broadcast to as many people as you want. The only caveat is your phone has to have data either through cell network or Wi-Fi, but when doesn’t that happen? We’re already thinking of dozens of cool ways we could use this thing.
$199.99 from Amazon Prime, Buy it here 
2/1/2017 The 100 Season 3 
It’s kind of crazy how The CW, a network previously best known for heated teen drama and lousy comedy, has turned into one of the best geek destinations on the TV dial. Their DC Comics shows cover a variety of space from the gritty Arrow to the endearingly kitschy Legends Of Tomorrow , but the real jewel in their crown is The 100 , a post-apocalyptic sci-fi show that’s about a million times better than it has any right to be.
When the Earth is ravaged by nuclear warfare, the only survivors are onboard a floating space station. Nearly a century later, resources are running thin, so they send 100 kids to the surface on a suicide mission to see if the planet is survivable. It is, but things don’t get any better from there. After this point is spoilers, but you can get caught up when Season 4 premieres tonight. Here’s the last season on Blu-Ray. Buy it.
$34.99 from Amazon Prime, Buy it here 
1/31/2017 Absolute All-Star Superman 
Happy 57th birthday to Grant Morrison, the chrome-domed Scottish chaos magician slash comic book artist who came up in the early days of Vertigo to turn into one of the industry’s most invigorating writers. Grant’s handled just about every big franchise in his career, from Batman to the X-Men, as well as creating a whole pile of original concepts. But if we had to pick one book from his massive library to really sell his skills, it would be All-Star Superman .
Working with frequent collaborator Frank Quitely, Morrison threw out half a century of continuity and cruft to pare the Man of Steel down to his essential elements, then explored them with heart. This is truly a Superman story for the ages, as over the course of twelve issues he deals with love, loss and his own mortality. It’s legit one of the best DC comics ever published, and this gorgeous oversized hardcover is the optimal way to enjoy it.
$75.00 from Amazon Prime, Buy it here 
1/30/2017 Particle Photon Wi-Fi Kit 
The Internet is all around us, connecting disparate elements of our lives with ease. If you’re anything like the Geek staff, you’ve got an Amazon Echo or a Google Home talking to smart light bubs, thermostats and other Internet of Things devices all over your apartment. But it’s time to take things to the next level and start hacking your own dumb devices to make them smart. The first thing you’ll need is a Particle Photon Wi-Fi Kit.
This affordable unit lets you add Ardunio-powered Wi-Fi functionality to pretty much anything you want, allowing you to easily and quickly control hardware through the Internet. From garage door openers to coffemakers to sex toys, if you can blueprint it you can use this puppy to run it. It even comes with free access to their cloud server so you don’t have to set up your own. And at just $19 it’s a hell of a deal.
$19.00 from Amazon Prime, Buy it here 
1/27/2017 Resident Evil 7 
Typically we use this space to highlight forgotten treasures and secret deals from deep in the bowels of Amazon’s massive warehouse, but you know what? We’re not doing anything but playing Resident Evil 7 and if you’re not, you need to be. Capcom’s flagship survival horror series has gone through some serious ups and downs since debuting in 1996. We’ve seen all-time classics and some very weird missteps.
RE7 returns the series to form while simultaneously pushing it forward. Like the very first game, the story takes place in a massive, crumbling house. Unlike the first, the action is now in first person, making the tension even harder to handle. And, for the first time, you can play it in VR. Play it in VR. It’ll scare the living hell right out of you. Early GOTY candidate right here, and it’s not even February.
$57.99 from Amazon Prime, Buy it here 
1/26/2017 Archie Vol. 1 
It’s getting so you can’t throw a brick these days without hitting a comic book adaptation on TV. Every network seems to have at least one show based on graphic literature, with the CW leading the pack with their interconnected DC universe. The latest offering, though, takes inspiration from a very different long-running comics universe. We’re talking about Riverdale , which morphs the world of Archie Andrews into a modern teen drama with all the angst that entails.
If your only memory of Archies is the corny little reprints you see at the grocery store, you haven’t been paying attention. The venerable publisher did a line-wide update a few years ago, bringing in top-flight talent like Mark Waid and Saga ‘s Fiona Staples to bring the titular character into the present day. The results have been great all around (with Chip Zdarsky’s Jughead book a special standout). Catch up on Archie’s pals and gals with this collection of the series’ first arc.
$12.18 from Amazon Prime, Buy it here 
1/25/2017 PocketLab 
It hasn’t been the best few days for science. The new guy in the Oval Office seems pretty determined to ignore anything that doesn’t directly bolster his existing worldview, and he’s instructed many of the government’s agencies to stop talking about stuff like climate change. But the pursuit of knowledge will persist no matter what, and the best thing you can do is become a “citizen scientist” of your own.
To wit, we’d like to introduce the Myriad PocketLab, a multi-sensor that works with any mobile device to measure a wide variety of physical forces, from motion and rotation to magnetism, pressure, temperature and more. All of that juicy data is fed into their app, where you can graph it, compare it, and upload it to share with the world. This kind of work is going to be pretty important in the years to come, so get on board now and let’s make some science.
$86.41 from Amazon Prime, Buy it here 
1/24/2017 HORI Real Arcade Pro Kai 
The evolution of console video game controllers has come a long way, from the Atari 2600’s joystick and single button, through the NES’s revolutionary D-pad, and on to modern devices with multiple analog sticks, shoulder buttons, touch pads and other assorted functionality. These controllers are damn good at playing most kinds of games, but for some genres you really have to go back to basics. If you play a lot of fighting games, old-school shooters or arcade classics, you need a stick.
The RAP Kai has HORI’s high-quality Hayabusa joystick and buttons, letting you hit your dragon punch inputs with arcade-perfect precision. It’s a very reasonably priced stick that works with PS3, PS4 and PCs. It’s also got a pile of extra functionality, including a touchpad, configurable buttons, turbo and more. If your home system doesn’t have one, this is an incredibly good deal.
$149.99 from Amazon Prime, Buy it here 
1/23/2017 Secret Wars II 
If you’re looking for the inflection point where the Marvel Universe transformed from a relatable world full of believable, if exaggerated characters into a constantly-escalating crossover hell, look no further. Secret Wars II was a line-wide crossover that spanned 1985 and 1986, touching every single corner of the Marvel universe in a bad way. When the omnipotent alien Beyonder comes to Earth, he basically just does a bunch of completely insane stuff for no reason.
Over the course of these nine issues and fifty million tie-ins, he turns a skyscraper into gold, kills and revives the New Mutants, falls in love with the Dazzler, and is taught how to go to the bathroom by Spider-Man. If you haven’t read it, it’s a gloriously weird slice of 80s cheese that some of Marvel’s biggest writers have been mining for ideas for the last two decades.
$16.92 from Amazon Prime, Buy it here 
1/20/2017 The Twilight Zone: The Complete Series 
Many Americans are waking up this morning feeling like they’ve stepped through a door “beyond that which is known to man. It is a dimension as vast as space and as timeless as infinity. It is the middle ground between light and shadow, between science and superstition, and it lies between the pit of man’s fears and the summit of his knowledge.” That’s the door to the Twilight Zone.
Now’s a better time than ever to re-watch Rod Serling’s five-season masterwork that introduced speculative fiction to a new generation of Americans. In 156 episodes, The Twilight Zone tackled a bevy of subjects with help from some of the era’s best TV actors. This sweet-ass Blu-Ray box set presents them all in pristine quality with a pile of bonus features.
$71.99 from Amazon Prime, Buy it here 
1/19/2017 Apocalypse Shovel 
You’re not alone if you’re thinking that things are seeming decidedly end-of-the-worldish right now. Russia is meddling in our government, the polar ice cap is cracking, Will & Grace is returning to TV. The signs are all there, and if you want to ride out the last days of humanity in relative comfort you need to gear up. I assume you’re already good on guns and food, so let’s talk tools.
The Apocalypse Shovel from master knifemaker Mykel Hawke is a lightweight survival tool that’s good for more than just digging holes. Within the knurled steel handle hides a variety of useful items, including a glass breaker, a bow drill for starting fires, a fixed blade knife and more. The shovel also features a pick axe for busting through tough soil. Made of hardened stainless steel treated with anti-corrosive finish, this baby will also slice through a zombie’s skull with ease.
$78.09 from Amazon Prime, Buy it here 
1/18/2017 Battle Royale: Director’s Cut 
Happy 70th birthday to Takeshi Kitano, the Japanese actor / director / game show host who has made his presence felt in just about every sphere of geek culture. From hosting Takeshi’s Castle , the wild obstacle course that would inspire dozens of imitators, to consulting on the NES game Takeshi’s Challenge , widely regarded as one of the most absurd and difficult pieces of software ever released, to directing and starring in lyrical, violent yakuza movies, Kitano has done it all.
American audiences first met him as the teacher in Battle Royale , Kinji Fukasaku’s bleak survival horror flick about a class of students forced to battle to the death on a remote island for their country’s televised entertainment. It was a remarkably prescient and brutal film, and Kitano’s laid-back authority figure provides an awesome dramatic fulcrum. If you haven’t seen it, get cracking.
$9.49 from Amazon Prime, Buy it here 
1/17/2017 Moon Girl & Devil Dinosaur 
We could probably fill an entire calendar just with characters created by the great Jack Kirby. The most prolific mind in comics history erupted ideas like a volcano, and most of them were keepers. January 17, 1978 saw the introduction of one of his most unusual creations – a cherry red Tyrannosaurus Rex dubbed Devil Dinosaur. In the pages of his own series, Devil and his hirsute primate partner Moon Boy tackled all sorts of prehistoric problems for nine issues before being cancelled.
Devil Dinosaur turned up again last year in the pages of Amy Reeder and Brandon Montclaire’s brilliant new series Moon Girl & Devil Dinosaur , paired up with nine year old Lunella Layfayette, the smartest person in the Marvel universe. This TPB of their first adventures is a cracking read, updating a sort of silly character for the modern world in a wonderful way.
$11.61 from Amazon Prime, Buy it here 
1/16/2017 March 
We’re taking most of the day off here, for obvious reasons, but given the events that took place over the weekend we wanted to share an Amazon deal that’s socially relevant. Not only is Georgia congressman John Lewis a true hero of the civil rights era, he’s also the only elected official in Washington to ever write a graphic novel. March tells the story of Lewis’s struggle, with kinetic, powerful art by Nate Powell.
Don’t take our word for it, though. March is the winner of a National Book Award, an Eisner award, it’s the first graphic novel to receive a Robert F. Kennedy Book Award… the list goes on. It’s an incredible accomplishment from a life full of them. We’re going to send a copy to Trump Tower. Maybe Barron will read it.
$29.99 from Amazon Prime, Buy it here 
1/13/2017 Anki Overdrive Starter Kit 
Yes, we’re all still reeling from the Nintendo Switch reveal, but let’s be realistic here: you’re going to need something to do until March, so the deals, like the spice, must flow. And today we’ve got a really hot bargain on one of the coolest evolutions of the RC car in some time. Anki Overdrive not only lets you control your vehicle with your mobile phone, it also features enemy cars with sophisticated AI routines, weaponry, variable tracks and more. It’s like playing F-Zero in meatspace.
If you dig it, the company offers a wide selection of track pieces, new cars and more fun and funky stuff. But you’ll get days of enjoyment out of just the basics. If you have nostalgic memories of slot car tracks in your weird bachelor uncle’s basement, this is the 21st century version, and it’s a sweet ass ride.
$119.99 from Amazon Prime, Buy it here 
1/12/2017 Rob Zombie Box Set 
2016 brought a lot of bummers, but at least Rob Zombie put out an album called “The Electric Warlock Acid Witch Satanic Orgy Celebration Dispenser,” so things weren’t all bad. Today is the 52nd birthday of the man born Robert Bartleh Cummings, who took shock-rock sensibilities to the big screen and revitalized the Halloween franchise. Sure, Zombie’s work isn’t for everyone, but we have to respect a self-professed geek who goes this deep into the culture.
It was hard to pick a single element of Zombie’s life to spotlight – did you know he was a production assistant on Pee-Wee’s Playhouse ? – but when we spotted this bargain-priced box set of House of 1000 Corpses and The Devil’s Rejects we knew we’d hit it. House was Zombie’s directorial debut, introducing us to the degenerate Firefly family, and it’s fine to have both of these movies (plus a sweet making-of documentary) in one place.
$13.57 from Amazon Prime, Buy it here 
1/11/2017 A Series Of Unfortunate Events: The Complete Wreck 
Netflix is going buckwild with the Original Series lately, seemingly dropping a new show every week. But one we’re really amped for is A Series Of Unfortunate Events , based on the book series by pseudonymous author Lemony Snicket. If all you know of this is the awful Jim Carrey movie, you’re in for a treat. The books are cracking adventure stories featuring the three Baudelaire orphans eluding the wiles of the malevolent Count Olaf, crammed with wit and surprising darkness.
Typically we’d offer you a great deal on the first volume and trust you’d be hooked from there, but you know what? Why waste time. The Netflix series premieres this weekend, and you want to be ahead of the curve. Here’s a gorgeous hardcover set of all 13 books for an insanely low price. Clear some shelf space, dummy.
$111.45 from Amazon Prime, Buy it here 
1/10/2017 SubPac M2 Wearable Physical Sound System 
Video gaming now is all about the immersion. We’re strapping VR headsets to our faces and diving into the most realistic worlds ever built. But those only really satisfy one of our five senses. We’re not asking to smell the stables in Skyrim or anything, but hardware could certainly do better. One of the sweetest ways to beef up your audio footprint comes in the form of the SubPac M2 Wearable Physical Sound System, which takes your crappy desktop speakers and replaces them with a vest that channels audio right through your body.
Designed by a startup, this device either connects by Bluetooth or aux cord to your audio system and creates bass vibrations that you can feel through your whole body. That means that grenade explosions rattle your bones and gunshots give you real recoil. Play with one of these once and you’ll never want to game without it.
$349.00 from Amazon Prime, Buy it here 
1/9/2017 Tintin In America 
What were you doing when you were 14 years old? Probably playing a lot of video games, drinking a lot of soda, trying to work up the nerve to talk to girls (or boys). But on January 10, 1929, the comics world was introduced to one of the most badass teenagers of all time: Tintin, the globe-trotting boy reporter who would risk everything for a story. Herge’s hero can drive a tank, fly a plane, punch a thug in the jaw and is a crack shot with pistol or rifle, and his adventures still hold up nearly a century later.
If by some bizarre anti-miracle you’ve never gotten into Tintin , take advantage of this great deal on the third volume of his adventures, Tintin In America . This was where Herge really started to hit his stride, with a great tale of Tintin on the trail of gangsters in Chicago and Blackfoot in the Wild West. It’s a cracking read that will leave you thirsty for more.
$9.07 from Amazon Prime, Buy it here 
1/6/2017 Eight Pounds Of Cereal Marshmallows 
It takes a tremendous amount of energy to get us through the day. We’re always running at 110% to bring you the best of geek culture, and that combined with epic Nerf wars, VR deep dives and jeet kune do classes makes us very, very hungry. That’s why we’ve been buying eight pound bags of cereal marshmallows from Amazon and turning to them every time we need a quick boost.
The humble cereal marshmallow was invented in the 1960s with the debut of Lucky Charms, and it’s almost hard to believe that they’re the same thing as you use to make s’mores. Cereal marshmallows are made with a process that removes as much water as possible, making them shelf-stable for years. While an eight pound bag might seem like overkill, you’ll be surprised at how fast these babies disappear even without any milk around.
$41.99 from Amazon Prime, Buy it here 
1/5/2017 Video Games You Will Never Play 
Game development can be a cruel mistress. The effort it takes to steer a title from conception to completion is massive and only getting bigger. That’s why it shouldn’t surprise you that, like baby turtles, many games don’t make it out the door. Some studios shut down, some publishers pull out, and sometimes they just don’t come together. 10/3/2016 Cage Are you done binging on Luke Cage ‘s first season yet? If Netflix’s latest adventure in the Marvel Cinematic Universe has whet your appetite for a little more action, why not delve into the back issues? You could certainly start from the beginning with the ’70s Power Man book, but for something a little closer to the modern take, Brian Azzarello, and Richard Corben’s five-issue Cage miniseries will hit the spot.
Azzarello is famous for 100 Bullets and other titles, and Corben is a legendary underground artist who cut his teeth in the pages of Heavy Metal . His mainstream work is few and far between, so this is a rare treat. Published under Marvel’s Max imprint (sort of a “mature readers” line akin to Vertigo, but less fantasy-oriented and more gritty action), this book brings Luke Cage back to the streets, putting him in the middle of a gang war as he looks to solve the murder of a little girl.
Corben’s art is gorgeous, the script hews close to the character’s Blaxploitation roots, and it’s an interesting midway point between the tiara-wearing Hero for Hire and the devoted family man and Avenger that he became. Very much worth reading, especially at this price.
